comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was there in the past year or so and took a few shots of that view.  I like the little steam powered boat having just pushed off from the quayside.  The boat on the left looks very well built with a clinker hull looking very well indeed.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I believe the curvy ironwork lamps are gone now though...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: They're not curvy ironwork lamps - they're davits for lifting boats in and out of the water!  They look like they were removable but yes they were not to be seen.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Well, colour me embarrassed! I was misinformed on the davits, and thanks for that very useful tag. There were lamps there somewhere though, which aren't nowadays.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: There is just something about these old pictures that is so charming, catching and preserving that one moment in time that we get to enjoy seeing now. Thank you for sharing.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] You're more than welcome! And delighted you wanted to add so many of our photos to your groups.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I think this may be another photo to do with the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, Earl Dudley, who used Rockingham as his country residence from 1903 to 1905. I can't be 100% sure but I think the man standing on the Dock might be Lord Dudley. There is a photo of Lord Dudley in his Panhard car in The Motor Car journal of 1904 . It looks like this was taken at Rockingham and he is wearing a cap similar to the one the man on the right in the photo above is wearing. The flag appears to be a white ensign which only the Royal Navy and the Royal Yacht Club could use. Lord Dudley was a competitive yachtsman and a member of the Royal Yacht club who would have had the right to use the flag.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] How old do you estimate he would have been here then?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] If its him he would have been about 36 or 37. He was relatively young I think for a Lord Lieutenant. He was a very active man who enjoyed sailing, golfing and motoring. He was also the first Lord Lieutenant of Ireland to use a motor car.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] And Paul, is he the same Lord Lieutenant/Earl Dudley as in our Dublin Lockout photo?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: He was only Lord Lieutenant from 1902 to 1905. John Hamilton-Gordon, 1st Marquess of Aberdeen and Temair was his successor and held the office until 1915.
